page.title: Adam Koprowski :: Coq and rewriting
page.content:
What Coq and rewriting: a series of 3 lectures/lab sessions given as part of the advanced track of the 5th International School on Rewriting (ISR '10) in Utrecht, Netherlands.
Abstract
Coq is an interactive theorem prover. On the one hand it allows to express mathematical theorems and mechanically check correctness of their proofs. On the other hand it encompasses a functional programming language, allowing to write programs within the system and reason about their correctness, hence providing a software verification platform. This course will:
introduce Coq as a tool;
present recent work in the term rewriting community on using theorem proving technology to certify termination proofs for term rewriting systems; and
include lab sessions, where students will be presented with a number of exercises, giving them an opportunity to have a hands-on experience with the system.
Coq installation
WARNING! All students taking part in this course are expected to have a working version of Coq pre-installed when joining the course. Please follow the instructions below and in case of any problems contact me.
What you will need to take part in this course is:
Coq 8.2pl1 -- you can download it here. If you are running Linux (preferred platform for Coq developments) you may need to install it from sources. For more information see: Coq installation tutorial (courtesy of Arthur Charguéraud).
An interface to Coq: i.e. either ProofGeneral (preferred) or CoqIDE. CoqIDE comes bundled with standard Coq distribution. For ProofGeneral you will need to have (X)emacs on your system and then follow instructions from: Proof General's download page.
Please do this installation well in advance of the course, so that I will be able to assist you in case you run into any problems. There will be no time during the course to do that!
